comments.commentBody: Tax loophole for corporations...means every American gets to chip in to pay the fine by making up the after tax value of the fine amount write off with OUR tax dollars...Congress and Corporate Lobbyists working together for a brighter America.

HSBC was a prime opportunity to shut down a Charter in the US.  But let's face it.  If they won't shut a bank down for repeatedly money laundering billions for Mexican drug cartels when would they EVER shut one of these criminal banking operations down?  We need Teddy Roosevelt!

I find Dimon to be the most politically savvy CEO's in the country. I was impressed when he announced the clawbacks from bankers/traders involved in "Whale" debacle. Americans are so disgusted with banking scandals and have so much distrust of bankers and since he's survived the scandal with shareholders he's got a real opportunity to "fall on his sword" by admitting wrong doing. Paradoxically, he'll be a hero amd JPMorgan esteemed as trustworthy.
Pilates or Yoga.... Boolean "or" here. Do both.  Both offer great benefits.

The veracity is this article is questionable given the statement " ... incinerated body fat apart from in the midsection."  There are no exercises that can spot reduce fat.  Without facts not myths taking anything here as viable info is useless.

Yoga is not just for skinny people!  I attend a yoga class with women and men of all ages and body types.  I am no sylph, but I feel much happier and stronger when I practice yoga.  If you ask around, you can find a teacher who will be a good match for you.
I found both helpful in slimming down in conjuction with adjusting  diet.  Feeling better in your own skin makes you want to eat better, IMO.   Take the first step!

I'm sorry you have had a disappointing experience.  Everything can be modified and you can be supported while you begin either a pilates or yoga practice.  A place where I do yoga has a chair yoga class.  My former pilates instructor had many clients who were either overweight (as I was) or obese or in their 70's-80's.  If you can, try to invest in a few private lessons so that you can learn the lingo and get a bit of body memory.  Also look for the words "gentle" or "recovery" or "injury recovery" for a yoga class, all of which are going to be geared toward modifying the exercises and pace for several ability levels.
They are both for skinny people. I'm out.

True Pilates is not in any way a "subset of yoga poses." This is simple factual error. I'm sure there are mat classes out there taught by moonlighting yoga teachers and erroneously labelled Pilates, but they're doing it wrong. This is why it pays to check out the credentials and training of a teacher before taking their class.

Flexibility is not a requirement for yoga. All poses can be modified with props to take any lack of flexibility into account. All that is required is that the student be present, do the poses to the best of their ability, and breathe. But you are correct when you say that checking your ego at the door is an absolute requirement. Many aspiring yogis hurt themselves by pushing too far, too fast because they want to keep up with those around them. Keep your yoga on your mat.

In hatha yoga ,one also needs to keep focus on the actual pose one is doing. I find I have 'injured' myself only when my mind wanders and I lose my  focus & concentration. My mind is 'weaker' than my body sometimes ;-)

This is an interesting article and so are the comments here. I am a practitioner of both kinds of exercise. The fact often overlooked is that Pilates poses are all a subset of Yoga poses. The main difference between Yoga and Pilates is that Pilates is a dynamic exercise where motion has been added to the Yoga poses. In Yoga, one is traditionally supposed to maintain the poses statically for some time. [I do not know exactly how Joseph Pilates designed the moves, but I am pretty sure he was influenced by Yoga - I would call Pilates "yoga-inspired" exercise.] Given this insight, the question which exercise is better seems irrelevant to me. Yoga is way broader than sun salutations or core exercises and certainly way broader than Pilates (even for the core, Yoga has more poses than Pilates). A proper Yoga exercise routine (including core strengthening poses) not only strengthens and builds muscles throughout the body (including core), but also builds flexibility. Yoga being dangerous is a very ludicrous suggestion: I would like to know of an exercise that is not dangerous if performed improperly. This suggestion comes from people who either lack the flexibility to perform Yoga and are too negative to try it, or people who have injured themselves performing Yoga improperly. One thing is certain - to perform Yoga properly and without injury, the first thing the practitioner needs to give up is the ego that many athletes and trainers appear to be driven by in the West.
That may be true in the West - primarily because performing yoga safely requires strong control over ego and mind. Yoga is a combined body and mind practice.

@Paul
I disagree. Yoga arm balances require maintaining the full weight of the body on the arms for a period of time. I have seen my arms become big and my ability to lift heavy weights go up SUBSTANTIALLY by practising yoga poses.
One interesting observation - I regularly attend Yoga classes in my gym and guys who are used to lifting heavy weights find some strength testing Yoga poses rather challenging.

@jona
Every exercise is dangerous if you do not do it properly. I can only say that either your instructor was not well-qualified or you did not control your ego and listen to your instructor.

"In yoga the (physical) aim is to stregthen the back body and let go of the gripping or clenching tendency of the front body." That is factually incorrect. There are Yoga poses to strengthen the back and there are yoga poses to strengthen the front. Also, Yoga poses are way more muscle-based than Pilates. How can maintaining the full weight of your body on your arms (arm balances) not involve muscles?

"Pilate-because it's less "open source" more regulated, more disciplined and less entertaining than yoga, it's less accessible to general public." As a practitioner of both forms of exercise, I can say that is actually just the opposite. Yoga is a way more disciplined practice that requires control over mind and body when performing. The smiling faces of women performing yoga on the beach as if it were child's play constitute a very misleading picture of Yoga. No doubt, performing a pose becomes fun once one has mastered it and that is one among the great benefits of Yoga - you just cannot help loving it once you know how to do it, but learning a Yoga pose and learning to hold it can be very challenging if one lacks the muscle strength and flexibility and does not follow the scientific technique of the pose.
"Pilates..requires a lot more time involvement to advance; few people has the time or money to advance to higher level where every muscles are addressed." Again incorrect. Learning a new Yoga pose can be very challenging and requires a lot of practice, but once learnt, Yoga is one of the best ways to build muscle strength and flexibility in every part of the body, including the smaller muscles of the body that the usual weight-lifting routine completely overlooks.

Good point. But it is important to also note that "Yoga", as used in the West, is the colloquial term for Hatha Yoga. And Hatha Yoga is actually a form of exercise. The purpose of Hatha Yoga is purely to benefit health and skeleto-muscular system through a series of physical and breath exercises. That concept of "attaining a state of permanent peace" is the concept of the broader term Yoga, as used in the literal sense. So, I think it is completely fair to compare Hatha Yoga with other forms of exercise. However, one should note that Hatha Yoga requires and builds physical as well as mental strength - it is therefore a combined mind and body practice, this point is very often ignored in the West. Hatha Yoga is not the only form of exercise that requires and builds strength of mind. To some extent, strength of mind is involved in some other exercises such as high-intensity cardio and weight-lifting. Preforming hatha yoga safely, however, does require the practitioner to be mindful when performing the exercise, and this is where Yoga training differs from other exercises where you may be able to mindlessly perform and repeat a move.

For Amit:  Asana practice (aka yoga) is intended to increase the body's flexibility and endurance so that the practitioner can sit in meditation for longer and longer periods. To divorce the practice of asana from its end purpose is to pretty much miss the entire point.

@ Lucy
Appreciate your comment. Unfortunately, the essence of your argument is something like: Because Pilates was developed for rehabilitation, Pilates cannot be considered exercise because one should not perform Pilates unless one has had some pain/ injury. OR Because most martial arts in their present form were developed by Buddhist monks for protection against royal persecution, we cannot separate martial arts from a royal threat of persecution.
As a matter of fact, most exercises (two exceptions that come to mind are the cardio and decorative weight-lifting in the West) have a serious purpose - the purpose of strengthening or defending the body. Hatha Yoga is exactly the same. I can understand that owing to cultural difference, this can be difficult to understand, but in Indian culture, Yoga (in the literal sense) is the sole purpose of life and Hatha Yoga prepares the body for it. Hatha Yoga has little to do with "peace" and "meditation" - those connotations are purely a figment of imagination in the West. "Peace" and "happiness" are two of GENERALLY sought after goals of life in Hinduism. "Meditation" is JUST ONE way of attaining that, and nothing prepares the body for meditation better than Asanas and Pranayama. But whether the practitioner of Asanas goes on further to perform meditation is his/ her own wish. He may as well choose to attain his/ her life goals by "Karma" for example, which is the way of work - basically this is what most of us do in today's world.

I knew a health and exercise "expert" when I was living in Europe who barely knew how to spell exercise and or how the body and mind really worked in conjunction with each other. She would attempt to show off her knowledge at parties only to be proven wrong at every step along the way by real experts in health, nutrition and physical fitness. But people read her and believed in her, until the editors smartened up and fired her. She never really worked in newspapers again. So she wrote a book. She was noted and also wrote random articles on best health practices in obscure journals. Whenever we met I wondered how she got the job as a so called 'expert' in exercise and health at all. Ahhh, publicity! Publicity!

Yoga is a commonly known generic term for the physical, mental, and spiritual practices or disciplines which originated in Ancient India with a view to attain a state of permanent peace. OK, that's from Wikipedia but not far from the understanding I have learned over the years. I emphasize 'permanent peace'.

Pilates is form of exercise.

To publish a single story about two different systems, with two different functions and two different goals as different as politics and love, is akin to comparing something substantial and proven over the centuries, with new age exercise and makes no sense to me.

How about a real article about benefits of Yoga? And a separate real article about Pilates?

I emphasize real. By experts, real experts.

The weirdness of quantum mechanics is the reason why I gave up on the theory. Quantum mechanics complicates things. Albert Einstein once said, "So the moon exists because a mouse is present to observe it?" He strongly disagreed with quantum mechanics. I am on Einstein's side, especially after reading a great book on quantum field theory written in layman terms. "Fields of Color: The theory that escaped Einstein" written by Rodney Brooks was the first time I heard about quantum field theory (he does a great job explaining it!) I would recommend the book to anybody who is interested in the book. Introduction to his book is here... http://www.quantum-field-theory.net.

"Why is it all right for private insurers to have death panels but not for Medicare to have lesser limits?"

You've obviously been skipping your Kool-Aid. Please drink deeply, then remember: the miraculous magic of the market ensures that anything, anything a private enterprise does is entirely rational, maximally efficient, and the only way to bring about Good Things. Meanwhile anything, anything, a public entity does is a wasteful monstrosity of bungled inefficiency.

Stop looking at evidence! Stop paying attention to logic. These things are ephemeral distractions from the deep truths in the Kool Aid. Drink some more... then subscribe to the WSJ and feel the power flowing through you, revel in how it All Makes Sense, in this best of all possible capitalist worlds.

You are absolutely correct. When my own parents were both simultaneously terminally ill with lung cancer, they opted for in-home hospice care.
The hospice program in their Pennsylvania county was administered through the county nurses' association. When my parents enrolled in the program, we were provided some reading materials, as well as an agreement to sign which said, among other things, that we were agreeing NOT to call 911. It was clearly understood that in supporting them in this hospice program, we were aiding them in the process of dying.

Fortunately, in my family's case, we had a wonderful experience with the hospice nurses that both tended to my parents and supported me and my siblings through the process.
I agree--I'm sure the prosecutor wants to run for higher office.

Frank is, of course, right again. The nurse and her dad should have been left alone - BUT if that prosecutor wanted to EVER get elected to the state legislature or he governor's mansion, he had to protect himself from the inevitable opponent who would rwist this into his being lax on murder.

I must admit that when I first saw the title, I immediately thought that Frank had been awakened to a terrible form of racism known as those lowered expectations while guilt-filled liberals follow as they do the worst thing to black and other minorities: deprive them of their ability to hit bottom, pay the consequences of their mistakes like the rest of us did, and regain their own self-respect. But, of course, self-respect must be erased if a permanent underclass is to be cultivated for the greater good of dependable voters for ever larger government.

So, yes, the prosecutor was nuts to go after the nurse, and the decorated vet should have had the one thing he wanted, to die at home. But busybodies never know when to stop, do they?
Hands up for Rex Stout!!

The trouble with suicide by gun is that it's messy.  At least with a pill you can leave behind a peaceful looking corpse.  I imagine this would be prefered by anyone who'e going to have a funeral--especially if they or their relatives want an open casket.
Unfortunately, in Washington you have to register with a political party to participate in the caucus.

I don't know of any candidate I can trust or support. I hear all the speeches, but no longer am enticed by charismatics. Trusted Democrats are now Neoliberals. Republicans are going far Right of Right it's scary, and both have one thing in common, they are beholden to a higher authority that's not the voters. It could be ALEC or the Democratic form of ALEC.
Elizabeth Warren does seem to be the only Independent of the Democrats. But I doubt she would want the job.

This is why I feel I have to change my affiliation to Independent. I think the more Independents out there, the better our chances of getting a candidate who will have to break off from the lobbyists and contributors and start representing the people.
ah.... ah.... ah... #$%@&!!!!....gesundheit!
Deadline, I've thought you were confused all along.  I'm glad you've made it official.  Maybe you need glasses to see the X?

Ron, this is completely inconsistent with your previous writings. Previous to this, you advocated printing money to pay for debts independent of the markets. Now you are claiming that the congress needs to include the treasury in such actions.

Which is it with you? Do we need the treasury, and thus does it have to be labeled fiscal? Or rather is this a monetary issue that can be handled without the treasury?

We get that Ricardian equivalence was something worth including in arguments because of the rational expectations takeover of the profession, but unfortunately, Ricardian equivalence is and always was a Red Herring.  It is absolutely ridiculous.  Ridiculous.

sas --- I pleased you agree.

arty --- Gen 4 already exists. The Russians have one and are building another larger one. They then will build a really big one. In the west, the GE-Hitachi S-PRISM, 311 MWe, is available for purchase and the British are considering buying two.
